question: What is the importance of choosing the right provider in getting the most value out of your health insurance plan?
truth:
Choosing the right provider is an important part of getting the most value out of your health insurance plan. With Northwind Health Plus, you have access to an extensive network of in-network providers. Working with these providers is an essential part of getting the most value out of your plan.
[Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details-3.pdf]
answer:
Choosing the right provider is important for getting the most value out of your health insurance plan because:

1. In-network providers offer cost savings associated with your health insurance plan [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf].
2. In-network providers are more likely to accept the amount of payment offered by your health insurance plan, reducing your out-of-pocket costs [Northwind_Standard_Benefits_Details.pdf].
3. In-network providers may offer additional services or discounts that are not available with out-of-network providers [Northwind_Standard_Benefits_Details.pdf].
4. Continuity of care with the same provider over time leads to better quality of care and more effective treatments [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf].
5. Continuity of care helps providers have a better understanding of your medical history, leading to more personalized care [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf].
6. Staying with the same provider can help you save money by avoiding duplicate tests and procedures [Northwind_Standard_Benefits_Details.pdf].
7. Out-of-network providers may result in higher costs and a greater portion of the costs being your responsibility [Northwind_Standard_Benefits_Details.pdf].
8. There may be additional fees associated with receiving care from out-of-network providers [Northwind_Standard_Benefits_Details.pdf].
9. It is important to consider the availability and convenience of the provider in terms of location and schedule [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf].
10. It is recommended to choose an in-network provider whenever possible to get the best value for your health care expenses [Northwind_Standard_Benefits_Details.pdf].

Continuity of Care   HOW PROVIDERS AFFECT YOUR COSTS: CONTINUITY OF CARE   At Contoso, we understand the importance of providing our employees with access to a   quality, affordable health care plan. We are proud to offer our employees Northwind   Standard, an insurance plan that provides coverage for medical, vision, and dental services.   We also offer continuity of care, which is the ability to stay with the same provider for all   your health care needs, from routine checkups to specialized care.   Continuity of care is an important component of any health care plan, as it allows you to   develop a relationship with your doctor, who is more likely to recognize any changes in   your health and be able to provide better, more personalized care. With Northwind   Standard, you can stay with the same provider throughout your health care journey, helping   you to receive the best possible care.   Continuity of care also helps you save money on health care costs. When you stay with the   same provider, you are likely to pay less than if you switch around from provider to   provider. This is because your provider already has all your medical records, and you won’t   need to pay for expensive tests and procedures that you’ve already had done.   There are a few exceptions to the continuity of care. If you move to a different area, you may   need to find a new provider. Additionally, if you are in need of specialized care, such as   surgery or a complex treatment, you may need to visit a specialist who does not accept your   insurance plan. In these cases, you should be sure to check with your insurance company   and/or provider to make sure you understand any associated costs.

In-Network Providers   If you seek emergency care from an in-network provider, your plan will cover the cost of   treatment, including any necessary hospitalization and follow-up care. question: What should one consider when thinking about hospice care for a terminally ill family member under Northwind Health Plus?
truth:
If you are considering hospice care for a terminally ill family member, it is important to know that Northwind Health Plus covers some of the costs associated with hospice care. It is important to talk to your doctor about your options and what services are covered under Northwind.
[Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details-32.pdf]
answer:
When considering hospice care for a terminally ill family member under Northwind Health Plus, you should consider the following:

1. Northwind Health Plus provides coverage for hospice care services for terminally ill members with a life expectancy of six months or less [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf].
2. Hospice care services include care provided by a hospice care team, medications and medical supplies for the terminal illness, counseling services, inpatient and respite care, and grief counseling and bereavement services [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf].
3. Northwind Health Plus does not cover services related to treatment intended to cure the terminal illness, such as chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and surgery [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf].
4. It is important to talk to your doctor about your options and what services are covered under Northwind Health Plus [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf].
5. Different hospice care providers offer different services, so it is important to understand what services are offered and what is covered by Northwind Health Plus [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf].
6. Other services that may be available through hospice care include palliative care, bereavement services, and support groups [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf].

Note: If there are specific questions about coverage or services not addressed in the provided information, it is recommended to contact Northwind Health Plus for assistance.

WHAT IF I HAVE OTHER COVERAGE?   Coordinating Benefits With Other Health Care Plans   WHAT IF I HAVE OTHER COVERAGE?   Coordinating Benefits With Other Health Care Plans   If you have other health care coverage, such as Medicare or a health plan from another   employer, you may be able to coordinate benefits with Northwind Health Plus. Coordinating   benefits means that both plans work together to pay for covered services. This coordination   helps to ensure that you don’t pay more than you should for your health care.   When coordinating benefits, one plan pays first and the other plan pays what is left after the   first plan has paid. The plan that pays first is called the primary plan, and the plan that pays   second is called the secondary plan. Generally, the primary plan pays up to the amount of its   allowed amount for the services you received. The secondary plan then pays the difference   between what the primary plan paid and the total cost of the services.   The way in which you coordinate benefits will depend on the type of coverage you have.

question: What is the requirement for all services under the Northwind Health Plus plan?
truth:
All services under the Northwind Health Plus plan must be medically necessary, and prior authorization may be required for some services.
[Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details-54.pdf]
answer: The requirement for all services under the Northwind Health Plus plan is to provide a pre-service notice before receiving any services. This notice should include the name, address, and phone number of the provider, the type of service to be provided, and the estimated cost of the service. This notice should be provided to the insurance company at least 30 days before the date of service, or as soon as reasonably possible if the service is an emergency. Additionally, members are required to provide a post-service notice after receiving any services. question: What information is included in the prior authorization process for Northwind Health?
truth:
The prior authorization process for Northwind Health includes the patient’s diagnosis, the proposed treatment, the anticipated duration of the treatment, and any other relevant information that may be requested by Northwind Health.
[Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details-64.pdf]
answer:
The prior authorization process for Northwind Health includes the following information:

- Prior authorization is a process used to ensure that members receive medically necessary, cost-effective, and appropriate services [Northwind_Standard_Benefits_Details.pdf].
- Services that require prior authorization include hospital stays, certain laboratory tests, certain imaging services, physical therapy, durable medical equipment, and drugs not on the Northwind Standard formulary [Northwind_Standard_Benefits_Details.pdf].
- When a service requiring prior authorization is requested, Northwind Health will review the request and decide if it is medically necessary and covered under Northwind Standard. They will notify the member and their doctor of the decision within three business days [Northwind_Standard_Benefits_Details.pdf].
- If the service is approved, no additional pre-authorization is required. If the service is denied, the member may be able to appeal the decision [Northwind_Standard_Benefits_Details.pdf].
- The list of services exempt from prior authorization is subject to change, so it is important for doctors and healthcare providers to contact Northwind Health to determine if prior authorization is required [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf].
- When obtaining prior authorization, it is important to provide all necessary information, including the patient's diagnosis, proposed treatment, anticipated duration of treatment, and any other relevant information requested by Northwind Health [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf].
- Prior authorization is not a guarantee of payment, and the decision to authorize a service or treatment is based on the information provided and Northwind Health's policies and procedures [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf].
- Prior authorization is required for certain services and medications, including surgery, some imaging studies, physical therapy, and certain inpatient services and procedures [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf].
- Certain preventive services and routine check-ups do not require prior authorization, and Northwind Health Plus may waive the requirement for certain services and medications [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf].
- It is important to plan ahead and contact Northwind Health Plus before receiving a service or medication that may require prior authorization to ensure coverage [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf].
- If a service or medication is received without prior authorization, the member may be responsible for the entire cost and may be billed for services or medications determined to be not medically necessary [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf].
- Prior authorization can take several days to complete, and Northwind Health Plus may require additional information, such as medical records or lab results, to complete the process [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf].

Your doctor or health care provider should contact Northwind Health to   determine if prior authorization is required prior to providing care.   Exceptions to Prior Authorization   There are certain services and treatments that are exempt from prior authorization. These   include:    • Routine office visits   • Immunizations   • X-Ray services   • Emergency services   • Family planning services   • Maternity services   • Services and supplies related to diabetes   • Preventive care services   • Mental health and substance abuse services   • Routine eye exams   • Routine dental exams

question: What is the process of prior authorization in Northwind Health?
truth:
Prior authorization is a process in which Northwind Health reviews your request for coverage and decides whether or not it will cover the care that you have requested. To be approved for prior authorization, you must meet certain criteria and provide certain information.
[Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details-68.pdf]
answer: Prior authorization is a process used by Northwind Health to ensure that members receive medically necessary and appropriate services. Certain services, such as hospital stays, laboratory tests, imaging services, physical therapy, and durable medical equipment, require prior authorization before they can be received [Northwind_Standard_Benefits_Details.pdf]. When a service requires prior authorization, Northwind Health will review the request and decide if it is medically necessary and covered under the plan. They will notify the member and their doctor of the decision within three business days. If the service is approved, the member can receive it without additional pre-authorization. If the service is denied, the member may be able to appeal the decision [Northwind_Standard_Benefits_Details.pdf]. It is important to note that the list of services exempt from prior authorization is subject to change, so it is recommended to contact Northwind Health to determine if prior authorization is required [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf]. When obtaining prior authorization, it is important to provide all necessary information, including the patient's diagnosis, proposed treatment, anticipated duration of the treatment, and any other relevant information requested by Northwind Health [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf]. Prior authorization is not a guarantee of payment, and the decision to authorize a service or treatment is based on the information provided and Northwind Health's policies and procedures [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf]. It is recommended to contact Northwind Health as soon as possible for prior authorization to avoid delays in care [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf].

Coordinating Benefits With Other Health Care Plans   If you have other health care coverage, such as Medicare or a health plan from another   employer, you may be able to coordinate benefits with Northwind Health Plus. Coordinating   benefits means that both plans work together to pay for covered services. This coordination   helps to ensure that you don’t pay more than you should for your health care.   When coordinating benefits, one plan pays first and the other plan pays what is left after the   first plan has paid. The plan that pays first is called the primary plan, and the plan that pays   second is called the secondary plan. Generally, the primary plan pays up to the amount of its   allowed amount for the services you received. The secondary plan then pays the difference   between what the primary plan paid and the total cost of the services.   The way in which you coordinate benefits will depend on the type of coverage you have.

question: What should a member do if they have any disputes with Northwind Health Plus?

1. Contact Northwind Health Plus directly: Members can submit a complaint or appeal by phone, mail, or online [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf].
2. Contact the state insurance commissioner: Members can also contact the state insurance commissioner in their state [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf].
3. File a complaint or appeal with an external review organization: Members may be able to file a complaint or appeal with an independent external review organization [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf].
4. Contact an attorney: If not satisfied with the outcome of a complaint or appeal, members may be able to file a lawsuit in a court of law. They should contact an attorney for more information [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf].
5. Contact the Northwind Health Plus Member Services Department: If there is a complaint or grievance about their rights as a member, members can contact the Northwind Health Plus Member Services Department [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf].

It is important to provide as much information as possible when submitting a complaint or appeal, including any relevant documentation or evidence. Members should also be patient, as Northwind Health Plus typically responds within 30 days [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf].

question: What does Northwind Health Plus require from its members in order to receive services?
truth:
Northwind Health Plus requires members to provide certain notices and acknowledgments in order to receive services. It is important that members are aware of these, as they can affect the coverage they receive.
[Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details-99.pdf]
answer: Northwind Health Plus requires its members to be enrolled in the program in order to receive services [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf]. Members are also required to provide a pre-service notice before receiving any services, including the name, address, and phone number of the provider, the type of service, and the estimated cost of the service. This notice should be provided to the insurance company at least 30 days before the date of service [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf]. After receiving services, members are required to provide a post-service notice within 180 days of the date of service, including a description of the services provided, the date of service, the cost of the service, and any applicable discounts or adjustments [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf]. There are exceptions to the pre-service and post-service notice requirements for mental health, substance abuse, preventive care services, and services from out-of-network providers [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf].

In these cases, you should be sure to check with your insurance company   and/or provider to make sure you understand any associated costs.

This means that your doctor or health care provider will   need to get prior authorization from Northwind Health before providing the care. It is important for you to understand that prior authorization does not   guarantee that the service will be covered by your Northwind Health Plus plan. Your doctor or health care provider should contact Northwind Health to   determine if prior authorization is required prior to providing care. question: What are some exceptions to Coordination of Benefits (COB) rules?
truth:
There are a few exceptions to COB rules. If you are covered by Medicare, Medicaid, or a veterans’ health plan, Northwind Standard may pay first, even if the other plan is usually the primary payer. Additionally, if you are enrolled in a plan that is required by law to coordinate benefits, such as an employer-sponsored plan, Northwind Standard may pay first.

- Northwind Health Plus does not cover any expenses that are outside of the scope of coverage of the plan [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf]

- If you have Medicare coverage, it will be the primary coverage for medical expenses and Northwind Standard will be the secondary coverage [Northwind_Standard_Benefits_Details.pdf]

It’s also important to be aware of statements that are misleading because of their omission   of important information. question: What is the aim of Northwind Health in terms of member cooperation?
truth:

question: What are the responsibilities of a member when they sign up for the Northwind Standard plan?
truth:
When you sign up for the Northwind Standard plan, you are agreeing to certain responsibilities as a member of the plan. This includes being aware of the plan’s benefits and limitations, as well as your obligations under the plan.
[Northwind_Standard_Benefits_Details-91.pdf]
answer:
When a member signs up for the Northwind Standard plan, they have the following responsibilities [Northwind_Standard_Benefits_Details.pdf]:
1. Be aware of the plan's benefits and limitations, as well as their obligations under the plan.
2. Understand what expenses they are responsible for, such as co-payments or co-insurance amounts.
3. Seek pre-approval or authorization before receiving certain medical services, especially for specialty care like mental health and substance abuse treatment.
4. Stay informed about the plan's benefits, limitations, and requirements through the Northwind Health website, customer service representatives, plan documents, newsletters, and provider directories.
5. Use in-network providers as much as possible to maximize benefits and minimize out-of-pocket expenses.
6. Inform providers of any pre-existing conditions or special circumstances that could affect their care.
7. Follow up with providers to ensure proper billing to the plan.
8. Use preventive care benefits offered by the plan.
9. Contact Northwind Health with any questions about the plan.
10. Understand that there are exceptions to coverage, such as emergency services, mental health and substance abuse coverage, and out-of-network services. They should contact Northwind Health to verify coverage for these services.

question: What expenses does the Northwind Standard plan cover?
truth:
When you are enrolled in Northwind Standard, your plan will cover a portion of your medical and vision expenses.
[Northwind_Standard_Benefits_Details-91.pdf]
answer: The Northwind Standard plan covers preventive care services, such as immunizations, physical exams, and screenings [Northwind_Standard_Benefits_Details.pdf]. It does not cover emergency services, mental health and substance abuse services, or prescription drugs [Northwind_Standard_Benefits_Details.pdf]. The plan has a deductible of $2,000 per person per year, and once the deductible is met, there are co-payments and co-insurance. The co-payment is $30 for primary care visits and $50 for specialist visits, and the co-insurance is 20% of the remaining cost after the deductible [Northwind_Standard_Benefits_Details.pdf]. The out-of-pocket maximum for the plan is $6,000 per person per year, after which the plan covers 100% of expenses [Northwind_Standard_Benefits_Details.pdf].

Understanding How COB Affects Your Benefits   When COB applies, the primary and secondary payers will each pay a portion of the eligible   expenses and combined payments cannot exceed the total cost. Depending on the type of   service, the primary payer may pay all of the eligible expenses. When this happens, the   secondary payer may pay nothing.     For example, if you receive a medical bill for $1,000 and the primary payer pays $800, the   secondary payer will pay the remaining balance of $200. However, if the primary payer   pays the full $1,000, the secondary payer will not pay anything.   Tips for Working with COB   When you have multiple health insurance plans, it’s important to understand how COB   works and how it can affect your benefits. Here are a few tips to help you manage your   benefits:   • Make sure that each insurance company has all of the necessary information about your   other coverage, including plan numbers and policy dates.   • Confirm that your primary and secondary payers have updated information about each   other.   • Ask your health care providers to submit claims to both insurance companies.   • Understand any limitations or exclusions that may apply to your benefits.   • If you have questions, contact each insurance company for clarification.   Overall, it’s important to understand how COB works and how it affects your benefits. By   being aware of the rules and exceptions, you can ensure that you are getting the full   coverage you need from both insurance companies. question: What are the requirements for handling customer data at Contoso Electronics?
truth:
At Contoso Electronics, all customer data must be encrypted when stored or transferred, access to it must be restricted to authorized personnel only, and all devices used to store this data must be protected with up-to-date anti-virus and security software. Additionally, all passwords used to access customer data must be complex and regularly updated, and all customer data must be backed up regularly, stored securely, and destroyed securely when no longer needed.
[employee_handbook-8.pdf]
answer:
The requirements for handling customer data at Contoso Electronics are outlined in the employee handbook [employee_handbook.pdf]. Some of the requirements include:

- All employees must adhere to data security policies and procedures established by Contoso Electronics.
- All customer data must be encrypted when stored or transferred.
- Access to customer data must be restricted to authorized personnel only.
- All computers, servers, and other digital devices used to store customer data must be protected with up-to-date anti-virus and security software.
- All passwords used to access customer data must be complex and regularly updated.
- All customer data must be backed up regularly and stored securely.
- All customer data must be destroyed securely when no longer needed.

Additionally, all employees are required to complete data security training at the start of employment and annually thereafter [employee_handbook.pdf]. Contoso Electronics also conducts regular audits of their data security program [employee_handbook.pdf].

If you have any questions or concerns about Contoso Electronics' data security program, you can contact their data security team [employee_handbook.pdf].

question: What are the responsibilities of the financial manager in the organization?
truth:
The responsibilities include managing relationships with banks, investors, auditors, and other external financial partners, ensuring compliance with laws, regulations, and internal policies, monitoring cash flow, investments, and other financial metrics, analyzing financial data to maximize profits and improve financial performance, leading financial planning and forecasting efforts, overseeing contract management process, and supervising and mentoring a team of financial professionals.

- Supervising and mentoring a team of financial professionals [role_library.pdf]

question: What should one consider when deciding to seek emergency care from out-of-network providers?
truth:
When deciding to seek emergency care, it is important to consider the cost of out-of-network care. If you choose to receive care from an out-of-network provider, your out-of-pocket costs may be higher.

answer:
When deciding to seek emergency care from out-of-network providers, one should consider the following:

1. Higher out-of-pocket costs: Emergency services received from out-of-network providers will be covered, but you may be responsible for higher out-of-pocket costs such as copayments and coinsurance. You may also be responsible for paying the difference between the amount billed by the provider and the amount the plan will pay. [Northwind_Health_Plus_Benefits_Details.pdf]

2. Limited coverage: Northwind Health Plus does not cover certain types of emergency services, such as services for certain social and cosmetic procedures, elective surgery, experimental treatments, and services for injuries or illnesses that are not medically necessary. 3. Research and choose wisely: Before seeking urgent care, it is important to research and ensure that the facility is in-network. Out-of-network providers may result in higher cost-sharing amounts and may not offer additional services or discounts available to in-network providers. It is recommended to choose an in-network provider whenever possible to get the best value for healthcare expenses. 5. However, the cost of care may be more expensive, and you may be responsible for a greater portion of the costs. [Northwind_Standard_Benefits_Details.pdf]

A copayment is a fixed amount that you are expected to pay for a service.   The amount of the copayment varies based on the type of service received, whether the   service is rendered by an in-network or out-of-network provider, and other factors.    In-Network Copays:    For in-network services, copayments are generally lower than for out-of-network services. Out-of-Network Copays:    For out-of-network services, copayments are typically higher than for in-network services. Emergency Room   COVERED SERVICES - EMERGENCY SERVICES   At Contoso, we understand that unplanned medical emergencies can arise, and so our   insurance partner, Northwind Health, provides coverage for emergency services. This   coverage applies to both in-network and out-of-network providers.    In-Network Providers   If you seek emergency care from an in-network provider, your plan will cover the cost of   treatment, including any necessary hospitalization and follow-up care. Depending on the   type of plan you have, you may also be responsible for paying a copayment and/or   coinsurance.    Out-of-Network Providers   Emergency services received from out-of-network providers will also be covered, but you   may be responsible for higher out-of-pocket costs such as copayments and coinsurance. If   you receive services from an out-of-network provider, you may also be responsible for   paying the difference between the amount billed by the provider and the amount the plan   will pay.    Exceptions     Northwind Health Plus does not cover certain types of emergency services. These include   services for certain social and cosmetic procedures, elective surgery, experimental   treatments, and services for injuries or illnesses that are not medically necessary.    Tips for Employees   It is important to keep in mind that if you have an emergency, you should seek care from the   nearest hospital or medical facility.
